message_1:
Suppose you want to encrypt the plaintext "HELLO" using Hill cipher. If the key matrix is given as:

$\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 5 & 7 \end{pmatrix}$ 

with the corresponding encoding of the letters A to Z is 0 to 25, what is the ciphertext?
message_2:
To encrypt the plaintext "HELLO" using the Hill cipher with the given key matrix, we first need to convert the letters into their numerical equivalents using the given encoding (A=0, B=1, ..., Z=25):

H = 7, E = 4, L = 11, L = 11, O = 14

Since the key matrix is a 2x2 matrix, we need to break the plaintext into pairs of letters. If the plaintext has an odd number of letters, we can add an extra letter (e.g., 'X') to make it even. In this case, the plaintext is already even, so we can proceed with the pairs:

(7, 4), (11, 11), (14, -)

Now, we multiply each pair by the key matrix:

$\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 5 & 7 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 29 \\ 53 \end{pmatrix}$ (mod 26)

$\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 5 & 7 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 11 \\ 11 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 33 \\ 132 \end{pmatrix}$ (mod 26)

$\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 5 & 7 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 14 \\ - \end{pmatrix}$ (not needed since we have an even number of letters)

Now, we apply the modulo 26 operation to each element in the resulting matrices:

$\begin{pmatrix} 29 \\ 53 \end{pmatrix}$ (mod 26) = $\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$

$\begin{pmatrix} 33 \\ 132 \end{pmatrix}$ (mod 26) = $\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$

Finally, we convert the numerical values back into letters using the given encoding:

(3, 1) = D, B
(7, 4) = H, E

The ciphertext is "DBHE".
